and is what whonix say about zeronet:

This means users are not identified or reachable by an IP address, since they are identified by a public key - specifically a public Bitcoin address. The private key owner can sign and publish changes, which are propagated through the network. Sites are accessed through an ordinary browser in combination with the Zeronet application. [2] The BitTorrent technology refers to the use of trackers to negotiate peer connections. [3] ZeroNet can be optionally configured to use Tor for anonymity. [4]

The Zeronet wiki describes various features and benefits, including: [1]

    Password-less authorization - the user account is protected by the same cryptography that applies to Bitcoin wallets.
    Easy setup. [5]
    Immediate updating of sites in real time.
    Works with any browser.
    Full Tor network support, including onion services.
    Content cannot be censored (removed) after publication.
    It is impossible to shut down content, since content is served by any user who wishes to.
    ZeroNet is fast and works offline.

1612390130_1PGTHAmvu7K2PM7qqfoKyWv69aJsA.body:
Most libeay32.dll errors are related to missing or corrupt libeay32.dll files. Because libeay32.dll is an external file, it presents a great opportunity for something undesirable to occur.

Improperly shutting down your PC or getting a virus infection could corrupt the libeay32.dll, which could lead to dll errors. When your libeay32.dll file becomes corrupt, it cannot be loaded properly and will present an error message.

Other times, libeay32.dll file errors could be related to issues in the Windows registry. Broken DLL file references can prevent your dll file from registering properly, giving you a libeay32.dll error. These broken registry keys can be as a result of a missing DLL file, moved DLL file, or an leftover DLL file reference in your Windows registry from an unsuccessful software installation or uninstallation.

More specifically, these libeay32.dll errors can be caused by:

    Invalid or corrupt libeay32.dll registry entry.
    Virus or malware infection which has corrupted the libeay32.dll file.
    Electronic Arts, Inc. hardware failure, such as a bad hard drive, which has corrupted the libeay32.dll file.
    Another program overwrote the required version of libeay32.dll.
    Another program maliciously or mistakenly deleted the libeay32.dll file.
    Another program uninstalled the libeay32.dll file.
